posts.name: Brayden Durocher
posts.cooked: I am the programmer for Team 9699, and we switched to python this year, as well as using swerve drive, and we are looking for a team that has more experience using both python and swerve drive, so please DM me so we can set up a meeting if possible.

posts.name: Bryson Smith
posts.cooked:
What kind of swerve drive are you using? If you have an all rev or all ctre swerve, their templates would be very useful.

We use the SDS Mk4i with Neo motors on Spark Maxes for drive and turning with CANCoders to measure absolute rotation. I will not claim that our code is the best, but our robot is able to drive, which can at least be a starting point for you. Our code is here: GitHub - StolbergC/9445-Robot-2025 Let me know if you have any questions.

posts.name: Brayden Durocher
posts.cooked: We are using the SDS MK4i with 2 Krakenx60’s per module

posts.name: Bryson Smith
posts.cooked: Which absolute encoders are you using?

posts.name: Bryson Smith
posts.cooked: This is an encoder which does not reset its position by powering off. Circled is a CANCoder on the mk4i.

posts.name: Brayden Durocher
posts.cooked: Why would you need an external encoder when the Krakenx60 (powered by TalonFX) has one built in?

posts.name: Bryson Smith
posts.cooked: The Krakenx60 internal encoder is a relative one. It only tells you the difference in the position, not the absolute position. If you bought this module in a kit, you almost certainly bought and installed the absolute encoder. Could you send a picture of your module?

posts.name: Brayden Durocher
posts.cooked: I can send a picture on Thursday.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
We tried to jump in and code up a swerve drivetrain in Python from examples, including our robot code from last year, and struggled to debug it.

So, we put it on blocks, fired up the CTRE Tuner X, and ran through their swerve wizard. It can generate a project that’ll get the robot driving, but the whole creation process is super useful as you sort out if there’s any hardware issues. Like, possibly realizing you don’t have an absolute encoder installed. Or thinking your front left module is your back right module.

We ended up ditching everything but the ‘TunerConstants’ class that was generated by the wizard. That’s a technique I’m pretty happy with. Custom code on top of the wizard’s tuning output.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
It’s a spiffy app from CTRE . Very useful for updating firmware on your devices and testing them. It also has a wizard that takes you through making a swerve drive with their code. The wizard walks you through things like measuring distance between modules, what are your gear ratios for drive motors, steering motors, what the can ID’s are for everything, spins wheels one at a time to verify they’re turning the right direction, etc. When it’s done you’ve got working robot code and have made sure you’ve got your robot sorted out.

Oh, and a Pigeon. You’ll need some kind of gyro for heading. Pigeon is easier to work with than NavX IMHO.

posts.name: Brayden Durocher
posts.cooked: Would you just wire the encoder into the CAN Daisy-Chain?

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked:
Yes. For power, we run a 5 amp breaker that powers all 4 encoders. We use a Wago 5 port connecter to connect them all to one output. This gives each of them a little over 1 amp. When we first started with swerve this was the method recommended to us.

I am a programming and software guy, but unfortunately have no experience with the robotpy project/framework.

posts.name: Brayden Durocher
posts.cooked: You can’t just wire the encoders into the PDH ?

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Well not exactly, since you need a very low current and you can power all 4 of them from a single PDH port with a 5 amp breaker.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: We have one set of wires (+ and -) run from the pdh port to their own seperatre 5 port WAGO block. From there, each CANcoder power input wire gets connected to the respective block if that makes sense. One for +, one for -.

suggested_topics.title: Navx/Gyro Reset Failing/Error
suggested_topics.excerpt: We found the solution! The code for the navx changed from 2024 to 2025, where it doesn’t take the type we passed in to the gyro from last season.
